node.text:
Grief is, among many things, an excavation of self. There are days when all I want to do is push away, deny, avoid confronting the enormity of my loss. And there are days when talking feels comforting. And it matters to whom you talk.⁣
⁣
With the kind, genuine and human @elizabday, I found myself opening up in a rare and deep self-excavation. Afterwards, I cried and cried and then I felt, even if only briefly, a comforting lightness of being.

node.title: How To Fail With Elizabeth Day

node.text: “I also think that there is still very much a sense of our military history; that we still have a government that thinks that engaging with people is somehow doing them a favour, and I find that quite dangerous for our democracy...”

node.text:
From Susan Rice’s TOUGH LOVE:⁣
⁣
“I was conceived in Nigeria. Toward the end of their stay, Mom became pregnant with me, and I have long amused myself with the hypothesis that my origins in Nigeria, combined with my Irish and Jamaican ancestors, explain a lot both about my temperament and attraction to all things international.⁣
⁣
Dad, who had made it known early on that he did not want kids, greeted the news of Mom's pregnancy with something far less than enthusiasm, suggesting that Mom had tricked him into fatherhood. My mother hotly disputed this assertion, but in Dad's view this pregnancy was among the first things to undermine trust in their marriage, which mutually dissipated over time. Complicating matters, Mom discovered she was bearing twins, a girl and a boy. To the limited extent my dad had any interest in fatherhood, he wanted a boy.”

node.text:
I was delighted to pay my respects to a great man and a great thinker, His Eminence John Cardinal Onaiyekan, at the launch of the book LET THE TRUTH PREVAIL.⁣
⁣
How lovely to be surrounded by genuine goodwill, especially from the Catholic Religious.⁣
#stillonthisslowgriefdrivensearch

node.text:
Oyi nne ya. Always and forever.⁣
⁣
Greatest gift for a writer is to be read, properly and seriously. Thank you to Charles Aniagolu, for our @arisenewsofficial chat and for being the kind of reader every writer wants.⁣
⁣
Hair by me & makeup by @dmannysglow

node.text:
Grief is, among many things, an excavation of self. There are days when all I want to do is push away, deny, avoid confronting the enormity of my loss. And there are days when talking feels comforting. And it matters to whom you talk.⁣
⁣
With the kind, genuine and human @elizabday, I found myself opening up in a rare and deep self-excavation. Afterwards, I cried and cried and then I felt, even if only briefly, a comforting lightness of being.

node.text:
My sister-in-law T has been Usifo Ataga’s friend since their days in Federal Government College, Warri. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It was she who first told me that he had been brutally murdered.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
At his Service of Songs, T and his other loved ones spoke of how generous he was, how calm, how respectful, how loyal to his friends, how eager to learn, how he taught himself forex trading at 19 years old, how keen he was on reading and watching documentaries.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
There was the cousin from the village who said Usifo never looked down on him.⁣⁣
The friend who said Usifo shared his provisions with him in class one.⁣⁣
The architect who said Usifo gave him a chance when he was just starting out.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
There was the elder brother, broken by grief, who in the middle of a vote of thanks was interrupted by his own painful sobs. The younger sister fragile with her stifled grief. The friend Rotimi swirling in a mix of shock and pain, pointing at Usifo’s photo. The friend Onochie walking too slowly to the podium, as though reluctant to give a tribute, as though afraid that doing so would finally make it true. The cousin Frank still speaking of Usifo in the present tense.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
His wife, sad and silent, wrapped in black, and in her written tribute the heartrending words: "From my days of adolescence, we shared great and loving times together and I will cherish those memories forever. You were a good man, Sifo." 

Above all else, his mother’s tribute broke my heart: “My pain is that I could not monitor him in his last week.”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It is easy to forget in the scramble for clicks, in the frenzied spreading of rumours, in the hunger for the salacious and the outrageous, that actual human beings are involved. That this is a person who was loved by many people, including two daughters who now will be scarred for life. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
May justice be served. May his murderers be brought to justice. ⁣⁣
#justiceforusifo
*Edited.

node.text: Nwa Grace. Always and forever.

node.text:
Serious caption: Lovely bit from Bishop Kukah’s WITNESS TO JUSTICE: "How do we explain the moral numbness that has afflicted Nigeria now? Where did the sense of shame go to? What of those times when neighbour looked after neighbour? What of those times when the doors were open to the stranger in our midst?”⁣⁣
*⁣
More serious caption: On books and legs 😝

node.text: Pope Francis is a true inspiration. Thank you to L'Osservatore Romano,  for asking me to write a personal reflection on his encyclical "Fratelli Tutti." Lucid, realistic, and energizing in its love-filled courage.
